info.title: BlockAtlas
info.description: An app that allows the user to search for the closest matching U.S. Census variables based on a search query.

get.summary: Find a data set, e.g. Median Income.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Should be semantically similar to the target variable. AI Assistants should adjust the user's query to remove location info and re-phrase - 'median income by county in Nebraska' should be queried as 'median income'.

get.summary: Get data for a specific variable or a combination of variables and one or more locations within a region.

parameters.name: map_title
parameters.description: Title for the map, e.g. 'Median Income'

parameters.name: variable
parameters.description: The variable(s) for which data is to be retrieved. Just the key(s), e.g. 'B04006_023E' or a comma separated list of variables like 'B04006_023E,B04006_024E'. Behavior of comma-separated lists is determined by type param.

parameters.name: normalize_by
parameters.description: The variable to divide by. Use this whenever the user wants to find a percent, a proportion, or a per-capita value. For 'over 85 rate', divide 'People over 85' (B01001_025E) by 'People with age determined' (B01001_001E). The _001E variable within the same group (prefix) as the target variable is usually the best choice.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: must be 'combine' (add variables together) or 'compare' (show variables side by side). In 'compare' mode, each variable will be normalized separately, if applicable.

parameters.name: geography_type
parameters.description: If the user does not specify a location, use 'USA'.

parameters.name: place
parameters.description: The place for which data is to be retrieved (e.g. 'Arlington, VA', 'VA', 'United States')

parameters.name: years
parameters.description: e.g. 2019-2021 for change (2021 minus 2019), or 2019,2020,2021 to show side by side. 2021 is most recent - do not request 2022 or 2023. For 'growth rate' query, use 2020-2021 unless asked. Oldest available is 2010.
